quoteLast: when I was sent for, and I arrived at the spot where the body lay at between twenty and five-and-twenty minutes past.”
title: Mystery of the inn by the shore
author: Warden, Florence, 1857-1929; Kendrick, Charles, 1841-1914 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: There had obviously been a desperate struggle, for the carpet is disarranged, the remains of a vase lie scattered about the floor, and a clock had been knocked off the table. This clock, by the way, furnishes an important clue, for it had stopped at
quoteLast: , showing at what time the murder was committed.”
title:
Clubfoot the Avenger
Being some further adventures of Desmond Oakwood, of the Secret Service
author: Williams, Valentine, 1883-1946

quoteFirst: [2813] Caesar started ‘about sunset’ (_ad solis occasum_): the wind dropped ‘about midnight’ (_media circiter nocte_); and the drift ceased at daybreak (_orta luce_). The sun set at
quoteLast: ; and day broke about 3.20 a.m. It would be absurd to suppose that the voyage must have begun at the moment when the sun dipped under the horizon: we may fairly assume that it began at any time between 7 and 8. Similarly the drift may be assumed to have begun at any time between 11 p.m. and 1 a.m. Let us suppose that the wind lasted 5 hours, and the drift 3 hours.
title: Ancient Britain and the Invasions of Julius Caesar
author: Holmes, T. Rice (Thomas Rice), 1855-1933

quoteLast: Greatest elevation in latitude 41° 30′ will be 66° 18⅔′.
